PROTEST.deftext:
to object to, talk against, disapprove of

PROTEST is a word that has undergone a complete change of meaning. PROTEST used to mean to speak for something. This use is still found in the expression “to PROTEST your innocence"—that is, to declare or speak in favor of your innocence. Now, however, PROTEST usually means to speak against something.

“The loser PROTESTED the decision against him.”

“The college students PROTESTED against the war.”

“The workers PROTESTED that they weren’t paid enough.”

PROTEST is also a noun.

“They ignored our PROTESTS and cut down the tree anyway.”

ISOLATED.deftext:
alone, solitary, apart

ISOLATED comes from a Latin word meaning island. Someone or something that is ISOLATED is cut off, like an island, from other persons or things.

“We live on a very ISOLATED farm. There’s no one else for miles around.”

“The doctors said the patient should be kept ISOLATED so that he doesn’t give the disease to anyone else.”

To ISOLATE something is to put or keep it apart from others.

“We tried to ISOLATE the problems and solve them one by one.”

Other forms of the word: ISOLATE, v., ISOLATION, n.

DEDICATED.deftext:
devoted, committed, zealous

To DEDICATE something is to devote it to a particular use, person, or goal.

“She DEDICATED the book to her parents.”

“He DEDICATED his life to finding a cure for the common cold.”

Someone who is DEDICATED is devoted to a cause or a purpose.

“She is a very DEDICATED musician. She practices many hours every day.”

“They are DEDICATED to proving their father’s innocence.”

“There aren’t enough DEDICATED men in the party. Too many of them just don’t seem to care."

Other forms of the word: DEDICATE, v., DEDICATION, n.

FLAWLESS.deftext:
perfect, faultless

A FLAW is a faulty part of something, like a crack in a dish or an imperfection in a jewel. FLAWLESS means “having no FLAW.”

“The diamond was FLAWLESS. I have never seen such a perfect stone.”

“His FLAWLESS reputation was spoiled by that one stupid act.”

“Donna memorized the poem and then recited it FLAWLESSLY to the class.”

Many people choose bad as the meaning of FLAWLESS. Bad is just about the opposite in meaning of FLAWLESS. People who choose it perhaps know what a FLAW is, but do not know what the suffix -less means.

Other forms of the word: FLAW, n., FLAWLESSLY, adv.

DISRUPT.deftext:
to break up, throw into disorder

The rupt part of the word means break. It is also found in words like interrupt and rupture. To DISRUPT something is to break it apart, to destroy the way it normally works. Very often the word suggests that this is only happening for a short time.

“The electrical storm DISRUPTED telephone service for several hours.”

“His angry speech DISRUPTED the conference.”

“Her attempt to teach the class was totally DISRUPTED by the noise outside.”

“The painters DISRUPTED our office completely. We didn’t know where to find anything, where to sit, or what to do.”

Other forms of the word: DISRUPTION, n., DISRUPTIVE, adj.

FULFILL.deftext:
to carry out, complete, satisfy, accomplish

To FULFILL originally meant what it sounds like: to fill up, make full. It is no longer used in this way. Today it means to do something fully, to complete or accomplish it.

“Jane FULFILLED her promise to complete the job on time.”

“Alan has FULFILLED all the requirements for becoming a lifeguard.”

“This product FULFILLED all our expectations. It is just what we wanted.”

HORDE.deftext:
a crowd, mob, throng, swarm

A HORDE was originally a wandering tribe of Mongols (an Asian people). Today HORDE is used about any large number of people or things, especially when they are rough or savage.

“HORDES of fans pushed against the gates of the stadium screaming to be let in.”

“A HORDE of children tramped through the house, leaving their dirty fingerprints on everything.”

INTERNAL.deftext:
inner, interior

INTERNAL means “having to do with the inside” of something, inner. INTERNAL injuries are injuries suffered inside the body.

“The president claimed the foreign government was interfering in the INTERNAL affairs of his country.”

“They carefully removed the cover to get at the INTERNAL parts of the machine.”

The opposite of INTERNAL is external, which means outside, outer. See ex under Prefixes.

JUNCTION.deftext:
a joining, meeting place, union, connection

A JUNCTION is a joining, a coming together of two or more things. A JUNCTION is also a place where the joining occurs.

“They built a town at the JUNCTION of the two railroad lines"—that is, where the two lines met and crossed. The most popular wrong answer on the Pretest is dividing, which is an opposite of JUNCTION.

NUISANCE.deftext:
a bother, annoyance

A NUISANCE is a person or thing that causes trouble or worry to others.

“This table is in everyone’s way. It’s nothing but a NUISANCE.”

“That boy is making a NUISANCE of himself, teasing his sister while she’s trying to do her homework.”

“The hole in the sidewalk wasn’t really dangerous, but it was a NUISANCE for us to have to walk around it all the time.”

Complaint is the most popular wrong answer. A NUISANCE is likely to cause people to complain, but is not the complaint itself.

LOYAL.deftext:
faithful, true, devoted

To be LOYAL is to be devoted or faithful to a person, cause, or ideal.

“The brave soldier was LOYAL to his country and would not reveal military secrets even under torture.”

“The LOYAL dog jumped into the river to save its drowning master.”

LOYALTY, the noun form of the word, is the quality of being faithful.

“We admired the child’s constant LOYALTY to her aged father.”

Other forms of the word: LOYALTY, n.

POSSESS.deftext:
to have, own

To POSSESS something is to have it.

“She POSSESSES great wealth.”

“He POSSESSES a lot of charm.”

“This coin POSSESSES little value.”

POSSESSION is the owning or having of something.

“He came into POSSESSION of the painting.”

POSSESSIONS are things which someone has.

“All her POSSESSIONS were destroyed in the fire.”

Other forms of the word: POSSESSION, n., POSSESSIVE, adj.

DISTRESS.deftext:
to trouble, upset, disturb, bother

To DISTRESS someone is to cause him pain or sorrow.

“It DISTRESSES me to see you so unhappy.”

“She was DISTRESSED by the news of her husband’s disappearance.”

“We have received DISTRESSING news about an airplane crash.”

DISTRESS is also a noun, meaning suffering or misfortune.

“The ship radioed that it was in DISTRESS and was in danger of sinking.”

“He tried to relieve Susan’s DISTRESS by telling her that everything would turn out all right in the end.”

Other forms of the word: DISTRESSING, adj.

PRECIOUS.deftext:
valuable, costly, priceless, dear

PRECIOUS is related to the word price. Something that is PRECIOUS has a high price, is of great value.

“These PRECIOUS jewels are worth a fortune to us.”

PRECIOUS is also used about things which are of such value that they cannot be bought.

“My children are PRECIOUS to me. I wouldn’t do anything to harm them.”

“We have a few PRECIOUS hours in which to find the bomb before it goes off.”

Many people choose rare as the right answer. Often something is PRECIOUS because it is rare, but the two words do not have the same meaning.

PURSUE.deftext:
to chase, follow, go after

To PURSUE something is to follow after it. You can PURSUE anything: a car, a person, success, happiness, and so on.

“The police PVRSUED the escaped prisoner.”

“He was PURSUED by shouts as he left the meeting.”

“All people should have the right to PURSUE happiness.”

PURSUIT is the noun from PURSUE.

“Everyone joined in the PURSUIT of the criminal.”

Other forms of the word: PURSUIT, n.

questions.prompt: Do people usually PROTEST when they win a prize?
When a mother kisses her baby, is she ISOLATING it?
Would a DEDICATED teacher be likely to spend extra time helping her students?
Would an artist like to paint a FLAWLESS picture?
Would the noise of a jackhammer DISRUPT a concert?
If you keep a promise, have you FULFILLED it?
Would a HORDE usually be peaceful and friendly?
Is your hair an INTERNAL part of you?
Could your wrist be called the JUNCTION between your hand and your arm?
Would a boss want to hire workers who would be LOYAL to the company?
Can a person POSSESS a sense of humor?
Is it DISTRESSING to win a race?
Do you always catch something that you PURSUE?
They PROTESTED that there wasn't enough time to do what he wanted them to do.
Hermits are people who avoid the company of others and would rather be ISOLATED.
The mayor DEDICATED the new city hall to the people of the city.
Jack made only a couple of mistakes in his FLAWLESS performance.
The volcano looked like it was going to DISRUPT at any minute.
He FULFILLED the cup to overflowing.
The sudden arrival of HORDES of insects ruined the barbecue.
Bob opened up the machine to get at its INTERNAL parts.
This set of railroad tracks had many JUNCTIONS with other sets of tracks.
The dog became such a NUISANCE that finally we had to give it away.
Benedict Arnold showed his LOYALTY to the United States by giving secrets to the British.
He POSSESSED a magic ring that could make him invisible.
The teacher DISTRESSED to them the importance of studying hard.
His weekends are PRECIOUS to him. He won't let anyone disturb them.
He didn't care whom he hurt in his PURSUIT of great wealth.
